intro: Salvia × spiraeifolia, commonly known as the meadow sage, is a hybrid perennial plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 2 to 3 feet, featuring lance-shaped leaves with a grayish-green hue. Its showy, tubular flowers are usually purple or blue, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Salvia × spiraeifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade and is often used in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
